Today I paid a visit to the chairman of the main union of peasant farmers’ cooperatives in Belgrade, the former Prime minister – {{Vojislav Djordjevič}}.
I was asking the Minister about the current political situation

in Yugoslavia and about the circumstances this situation depends on. I was very happy that Minister Djordjevič did not talk to me as to a diplomat, rather as to a friend and a person from a country he got to know and held dear to his heart. I would like to point out that Djordjevič used to be a part of the government of Dr. Milan Stojadinović; therefore, he has been having a positive attitude towards the German Reich.

Yugoslavia is trying to keep the best possible relationship with Germany. The fact is that Germany does not want to break Yugoslavia. Because Yugoslavia's economic unit represents a better supply terrain for Germany than a splitted Yugoslavia. Furthermore, Germany regards Yugoslavia as its natural way to the Adriatic Sea. However, Germany is not satisfied with the current situation in Yugoslavia. It is not being appreciated that Yugoslavia is slow, or even hesitates, to adapt to the new ways represented by the German Reich. The current government is not sympathizing with Germany, since it was build upon the premises which are worthless nowadays, after the victory of the National Socialist ideology. To explain further, the government conciliated against the politics of Milan Stojadinović, who wanted to orientate the politics

of Yugoslavia towards Berlin and tried to present the country with the totalitarian regime. Today´s government stemmed from a democratic, pro-English and pro-French ideology, thus the ideology which is anti-German. Therefore, it can be said that this government is in a latent crisis and therefore so much is said about its resignation. The government was to resign already last week. It was because of the Jewish laws. Minister Korošec, who totally agrees with the politics of the German Reich, prepared the Jewish laws. These laws were, however, refused to be enacted by some of the government members. Dr. Korošec, therefore, stood in the government against Cvetkovic and Maček. The dispute ratchet up so that Dr. Korošec and the members of the cabinet who are standing in favour of a new direction of internal and foreign policy of Yugoslavia, i.e. Minister Vulović, Pantić, Bešlić and Krek, threatened a formal resignation. Only under the threat of the resignation, the laws were approved. These involved the Jewish Quotas and the prohibition of the Jewish trade in life needs in Yugoslavia. The laws were published, however, it is said behind the scenes that they are to be enacted very liberally. This is where the current government´s politics proves to be two-faced. It seems that Yugoslavia is facing huge political and personal changes. Minister Djordjevič indicated that it might go as far as it did in Romania. Prince Regent Pavel is a devoted anglophile and represents a regime which is intolerable to German politics. It is therefore expected that he will be forced to resign and the reign will be given to King Peter II, who is to be 18 years old only the upcoming year. There is a possibility that Korošec will become the Prime Minister.
